Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Perioperative Warming Strategies

Background: Perioperative hypothermia is a common complication in surgical settings, leading to adverse outcomes. This study evaluates the effectiveness of various warming strategies.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial was conducted in a hospital setting. Participants were adult surgical patients meeting specific eligibility criteria. The sample size was calculated to ensure adequate power. Participants were randomly assigned to either the intervention group receiving forced air warming (FAW) or the control group receiving passive warming methods. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Results: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the FAW group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021. The primary outcome was the maintenance of core body temperature, measured intraoperatively. Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the FAW group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach. The FAW group showed a significant improvement in core temperature maintenance (mean difference = 0.5Â°C, 95% CI 0.3 to 0.7; p < 0.01). Adverse events were reported in 3% of the FAW group and 1% of the control group, with mild severity.

Interpretation: FAW systems are effective in maintaining core temperature during surgery, reducing hypothermia-related complications. Trial registration: NCT12345678. Funding: Supported by the National Institute of Health.
